title: Drag Race UK Baga Chipz explains her politics after Tory comments
text:
Baga isn’t pro-Boris (Picture: Splash/Getty)

RuPaul’s Drag Race UK queen Baga Chipz has explained her politics, denying that she is a Tory.

The 29-year-old is one of the frontrunners on the first series of Drag Race UK, but was hit with some backlash prior to the premiere following comments she made to Boyz in 2017 about supporting Theresa May.

Baga wrote: ‘Theresa May served as our Home Secretary for seven years, working with communities up and down the country to keep us safe and to promote tolerance, but she also proved to be a capable politician, always on the ball and never at risk of having a “Diane Abbott” moment!’

She also claimed that May had changed her stance on LGBTQ+ rights, and called for ‘hard work, better education for all with a real choice for parents, an NHS that delivers for patients and a country with a strong economy’.

Baga is now a Corbynista (Picture: Splash News)

Baga met a host of politicians at the Pink News Awards (Picture: SplashNews.com)

However, Baga has explained that does not support current Tory leader and Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

Speaking to Metro.co.uk at the Pink News Awards, Baga – whose out-of-drag name is Leo Loren – said: ‘I’m not gonna lie, I supported Theresa May, but I don’t like Boris Johnson, I think he’s a t**t. I hate Trump. In America, I supported Hillary Clinton and Obama – I’m as liberal as they come. I just don’t really like the really far, far, far left politics where everything is free.

‘You need a balance to lead a country – good on LGBT rights but good on keeping the country safe, keeping the military and all that.’

Baga was never a fan of Corbyn, but after meeting the Labour leader at the Pink News Awards, she may have changed her mind.

Baga is one of the frontrunners on Drag Race UK (Picture: BBC/ Leigh Keily / Matt Burlem)

She said: ‘I love the Queen, and I don’t think Jeremy Corbyn’s a fan of the Queen.’

‘But I feel really bad, I’ve met Jeremy now and he’s a lovely man,’ she laughed. ‘I’m now a Corbynista!’

After the event, Baga tweeted: ‘I love this guy and I will vote for him in the next general election so kiss my fatty ass!!!!’ – so it looks like Corbyn has bagged a new celebrity fan.

Advertisement

The drag queen also spoke about transgender rights, following the news that transgender hate crimes have risen in the UK by 37% over the past year.

Baga said: ‘I take my hat off to [the trans community]. They have to deal with so much crap and people shouldn’t be judged for who they want to be. And it’s nobody’s business. Like my mum and my nan would say, if it don’t affect you, bugger off.’

Alongside Baga in RuPaul’s Drag Race, Crystal, The Vivienne, Blu Hydrangea, Vinegar Strokes, Cheryl Hole, Sum Ting Wong and Divina De Campo are competing to be crowned the UK’s next drag superstar.

RuPaul’s Drag Race UK is on Thursdays at 8pm on BBC Three.
